translated: The Mansion on the Plane of the Gods
The Divine Maiden’s Mansion🔽The Chapter about the Coral Tree
The Divine Maiden’s Mansion with Wide Eyes
“Who are you, with wide eyes,

analyzed: ramme citta latā vane  samantā anupariyāsi
translated: in the delightful, colorful forest grove?
You walk around surrounded by a crowd of women.

analyzed: yadā devā tāvatisā  pavisanti imam vana
translated: When the Thirty-Three Gods🔽enter this forest,
they all come here together with their chariots,
and they are colorful.
But when you enter this grove
and walk around,
your mind is not visible in your body.
By what means do you have such a form?
Goddess, please tell me
what the fruit of this deed is.”

original: “Yena kammena devinda,🔽rūpaṁ mayhaṁ gatī ca me;
analyzed: yena kammena devinda  rūpam gatī ca me
translated: “By what deed, lord of gods,🔽did I get my form and my destiny,
my psychic power and my influence?
Listen to it, lord of men.
In the delightful city of Rājagaha,
I was a laywoman named Sunandā.
I was endowed with faith and virtue,
and I always loved to share.
I gave clothing, food,
and lodging with a lamp,
to those who were upright
with a serene mind.
On the fourteenth, fifteenth,
and eighth of the fortnight,
and the eight precepts,
I observed the Uposatha,
always restrained in the precepts;
I was self-controlled and shared,
I dwelt in a heavenly mansion.
I abstained from killing living creatures,
and was restrained from false speech;
I was far from theft and sexual activity,
and far from drinking alcohol.
I delighted in the five training rules,
I was skilled in the noble truths;
I was a lay follower of the Visionary,
of the famous Gotama.
My slave in my family of relatives,
always brought me garlands;
I placed all of them
on the Blessed One’s memorial.

analyzed: uposathe caham gantvā  mālā gandha vilepana
translated: And on the Uposatha day I went,
with garlands, perfume, and ointments,🔽and placed them on the memorial,
with faith in my own hands.

original: Tena kammena devinda,🔽rūpaṁ mayhaṁ gatī ca me;
analyzed: tena kammena devinda  rūpam gatī ca me
translated: By that deed, Lord of the Gods,🔽my beauty and my destiny,
my psychic power and my influence,
are from placing the garland.
But as I was virtuous,
that has not yet ripened;
But my hope, Lord of the Gods,
is that I will be a Once-Returner.”
The Ninth Mansion of Visālakkhi.
